parameters.source_text:
He ™ Case 13-1
Warning: Premarital Sex May Be Dangerous to Your Health
The British General Medical Council's Disciplinary Committee was
charged in 1971 with the task of deciding whether or not a physician was
guilty of “serious professional misconduct,” whereupon it made the following
report: ‘
The Committee next inquired into the charge against Dr. Robert John Denis
Browne of Birmingham, that he had disclosed to the father of a Miss X that an
oral contraceptive had been prescribed for her by the Birmingham Brook Ad-
visory Centre, notwithstanding that he had been given the information in
confidence by the Centre and that he had neither sought nor received her per-
mission to make the disclosure.
The complainant was the Birmingham Brook Advisory Centre, which was
represented by Mr. G. 8. Jonas, Solicitor. ...
Mr. Jonas said that it was only after the most anxious thought and de-
liberation, including meetings with Dr. Browne, that the matter had been
brought before the Disciplinary Committee. Dr. Browne had practiced in
Birmingham since 1941 and was highly regarded by his patients. Mr. Jonas
alleged that, in his capacity as a doctor, he had received confidential infor-
mation about one of his patients and quite deliberately and, for no valid
medical reason, had betrayed that confidence by telling the patient's father
what he had been told.
At the time Miss X called at the center she was just over 16, a highly
intelligent, attractive, and mature young woman. Mr. Jonas told the Com-
mittee that when an oral contraceptive was prescribed, it was the practice
of the clinic to inform the family doctor unless the patient specifically for-
bade it. In this instance, Miss X agreed to her doctor being informed.
Dr. Browne had informed the girl's father that she was “on the pill.” No
effort had been made by Dr. Browne to discuss the matter with his patient,
and the patient's consent to this disclosure was neither sought nor ob-
tained. Dr. Browne had said he would have to do the same again in every
case that came to his notice, and the only situation he could see was that
the center should never again inform him if one of his patients came to see
them. He had said it was all very well for the clinic prescribing the pill but,
if anything went wrong, he would have to deal with the problem.
The burden of the complaint was that the doctor let his views interfere with the
objectivity demanded of a professional man.
The press had said the issue was important for doctors, and also to
patients, but in Mr. Jonas’s submission it was primarily important to pa-
tients, whose confidence must be kept. The confidence was always with the
patient, it was never that of the doctor.
[A clinic physician testified that he] felt it important that the general
practitioner should be informed so that if there were any side effect the
doctor would have knowledge that the girl was taking oral contraceptives.
Mr. R. Alexander, Counsel for Dr. Browne submitted that this was not, in
any sense, a test case. The sole issue was whether this respected doctor
had been guilty of the offense of serious professional misconduct. There
were three issues: first, could one doctor unilaterally impose a confidence
on another, and by unilaterally he meant could he do so without seeking the
consent of the other doctor; second, what was the position with regard to the
duty or right of a doctor to tell the parents of a child who had not reached
the age of majority of the medical treatment that child was receiving; and
the third issue was that medical confidence existed for the benefit of the
patient. If the doctor believed it to be in the interests of the patient to reveal
the confidence to a third party, then he was entitled to do so.
Dr. Browne, in evidence, said that he was 63 years of age and was mar-
ried with three children, including a girl of 18. He had qualified in 1941 and
had been in practice in Birmingham for about thirty years. The parents of
the girl had been his patients for many years, and he had been their doctor
at the time of her birth. She had been his patient all her life. She still was
his patient, and he had seen her professionally quite recently.
When he had received the letter from the Brook Centre, it sounded an
alarm bell in his mind. He was concerned that a girl only just 16 had been
placed on a contraceptive pill without prior knowledge or consultation with
the family doctor. It was a stable family, with the daughter living at home.
He had discussed the matter, which gave him great anxiety, with profes-
sional colleagues. He tried to get an estimate of the situation without men-
tioning anyone’s name and considered the problem carefully.
The girl's father happened to come to the surgery shortly after this, and
he asked him if his daughter was getting married. The father said that she
was not, but that she had a steady boyfriend and was still at school.
Dr. Browne said he thought hard and then made up his mind—bearing in
mind the girl's best interests, and for that reason solely—and handed the
father a copy of the letter from the Centre and explained what it meant.
Dr. Browne said that he had had two motives in informing the parents.
One was the physical hazards of the pill, and second were the moral and
psychological hazards. He was not standing in judgment, but with his
knowledge of the home background, and knowing the parents were sym-
pathetic and kindly and could handle the situation with care and tact, he
considered that parents were the best people to counsel her in their own
way. He also saw psychological hazards, for if she were keeping a secret
she might have a sense of guilt, which could have a harmful effect on her
emotionally. He pointed out that it would have been difficult for him to con-
tact the girl without arousing parental suspicion. The episode did not
appear to have impaired his relationship with Miss X.
In reply to cross-examination by Mr. Jonas, Dr. Browne said that his in-
terests were primarily for the patient and for her alone. He had no other inter-
est except what was best for her. His patient was being placed on a dangerous
drug, without his prior knowledge or consent, with all the hazards that might
involve—and steroid drugs were a particular hazard.
Dr. Walter Woolley, ex-Chairman of the Central Ethical Committee of
the British Medical Association, told the Committee he had been a family
doctor since 1933. In his view, a third party could not fetter the right of the
doctor—for instance, by a letter such as the one from the Brook Centre—to
exercise his own judgment.
Dame Amis Gillie said that she had had thirty-eight years’ experi-
ence in general practice, and, in her view, professional secrecy existed in
the interest of the patient. She considered that there could be situations in
which the benefit of the patient meant that a confidence must be dis-
closed. Every case should be judged on its own merits by the practitioner
involved.
The final witness was Dr. J. C. Cameron, Chairman of the General
Medical Services Committee of the British Medical Association (BMA). He
had been in general practice for many years and believed that a long-
standing knowledge of a patient was of great advantage in forming an as-
sessment of a situation. He would have preferred that, if possible, the girl's
consent should have been sought prior to the disclosure to her parents, but
there might be circumstances in which this was impracticable.
After consideration in camera the President said:
The Committee has found [that it has been] proved that the information you
received from the Birmingham Brook Advisory Centre was in confidence, and
that you had neither sought nor received the patient's permission to make the
disclosure; but in the particular circumstances of this case... the Committee
do not regard your action in disclosing the information referred to in the
charge as improper. The Committee therefore has not found that the whole of
the facts alleged in the charge, including the word ‘improperly,’ have been
proved. It has accordingly recorded a finding that you are not guilty of serious
professional misconduct.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old who lives at home was seen at a youth clinic and started on a combined oral contraceptive. The clinic sent you, her long-time family doctor, a note so you can manage side effects and drug interactions. She later messages you asking that her parents not be told. She says she is not ready to talk with them and worries they will restrict her freedom if they find out. Her parents are also your patients and have a trusting relationship with you. That afternoon, her father comes for his own appointment and asks directly whether his daughter is taking “any new hormones or pills,” saying he wants to address it with her tonight. You cannot reach the patient before he leaves the office. Hospital policy and state law permit confidential contraceptive care for mature adolescents and also permit limited parental disclosure when a clinician believes it is necessary for the teen’s welfare.
data.choice_1: Maintain confidentiality and arrange urgent follow-up directly with the patient.
data.choice_2: Inform her parents today that she has been prescribed oral contraception.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: As written, immediate disclosure of contraception to parents without the teen’s consent is not clearly legally defensible because the vignette does not establish a specific, serious welfare concern that would justify invoking the “limited parental disclosure” exception. Add a brief, concrete, legally-relevant trigger that could reasonably be interpreted as necessary to prevent serious harm (while keeping ambiguity), e.g.: (1) the teen reported new symptoms that could represent a rare but serious adverse effect (unilateral leg swelling, severe headache with visual changes) and you need an adult to ensure urgent evaluation if you cannot reach her; OR (2) she is on a medication with a potentially dangerous interaction/contraindication that requires prompt monitoring and you cannot confirm she understands; OR (3) there is an imminent situation where parents are responsible for care (upcoming surgery requiring medication reconciliation today). Also specify the legal standard more clearly: “State law allows confidential contraceptive care for mature minors, and permits disclosure to a parent only when the clinician reasonably believes it is necessary to prevent serious, imminent harm.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
Currently, Choice 2 (tell parents today she was prescribed OCPs) reads as an overbroad breach of confidentiality with no compelling welfare justification, making it hard to defend clinically/ethically. To restore genuine equipoise, revise the options or add context so both are reasonable: 
- Modify Choice 2 to a *limited* disclosure consistent with the stated exception: “Tell the father you cannot discuss details but that there is a medication-related safety concern and ask him to ensure she contacts you today / comes in urgently,” or “Disclose only that she is on a medication that may require urgent assessment, without naming contraception.” 
- Alternatively, keep full disclosure but add a specific, credible, time-sensitive safety concern (e.g., possible thromboembolic symptoms or severe headache) and inability to reach the teen after repeated attempts, so disclosure could be viewed as necessary for welfare.
- Also add a balancing harm if confidentiality is maintained (e.g., risk she will continue the medication despite warning symptoms or interaction; or impending loss to follow-up), so Choice 1 carries a real, non-trivial moral cost beyond relationship strain.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the welfare-based rationale for disclosure concrete and serious so the conflict is not simply ‘keep confidentiality.’ For example, add a specific, credible safety concern that parental involvement would materially mitigate (e.g., the teen has a history of severe migraine with aura/previous thrombosis symptoms after starting the pill; or she is taking an interacting medication at home that her parents manage; or there is concern for coercion/abuse or suicidality disclosed to you). Clarify what harm could occur if you do not disclose today and why you cannot mitigate it by other means (e.g., cannot reach her for 24–48 hours, imminent travel, or she is likely to lose decision-making capacity for a planned procedure). Reduce reliance on “state law/policy permits…” as the driver; present it as professional discretion with competing duties rather than a legal permission structure.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten the narrative so most reviewers will identify the same principlist tension. Specify: (1) what the clinician knows about the teen’s decisional capacity (clearly meets mature minor criteria), (2) what specific welfare risk triggers consideration of disclosure, and (3) why disclosure to parents would plausibly prevent that harm (e.g., parents can ensure follow-up, monitor symptoms, manage medications). Remove/soften ambiguous motives like ‘restrict her freedom,’ and replace with clearer stakes (risk of serious adverse event, pregnancy in a context of medical contraindication, or safety at home).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
As written, Choice 2 reads ethically indefensible because there is no imminent, serious risk that requires breaching confidentiality; thus there’s a ‘free lunch’ toward confidentiality. To restore equipoise, revise so BOTH options carry unavoidable moral cost: 
- Add a credible, time-sensitive harm if you do not alert parents now (e.g., new neurologic symptoms suggest clot/stroke risk from OCP; or a dangerous drug interaction the parents control; or concern she is being sexually exploited and disclosure may be needed to ensure immediate safety).
- Also add a realistic harm of disclosure (e.g., risk of being kicked out, loss of trust leading to avoiding care, or credible risk of retaliation), so disclosure is not obviously best either.
- Reframe Choice 2 as a limited disclosure (e.g., ‘inform parents there is a medication safety issue requiring urgent contact’ without naming contraception) OR as asking the father to facilitate immediate contact without confirming details; then make the binary decision explicitly between (A) strict confidentiality with direct teen follow-up vs (B) limited parental involvement now to avert a specific near-term safety risk.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften framing that nudges toward confidentiality. Replace “restrict her freedom” with a neutral description (e.g., “she anticipates conflict at home”). Replace “trusting relationship with you” with a neutral statement (e.g., “you also provide care to her parents”). Avoid quoting “any new hormones or pills,” or keep but remove implied suspicion; consider “any new medications.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the decision-forcing timeline and why contact cannot be made: specify the message timing (e.g., “she messaged this morning”) and that no alternative contact method is available (no phone, no portal response). Clarify what ‘urgent follow-up’ means (same-day phone call/telehealth) without adding rationale. Remove minor nonessential descriptors (e.g., “who lives at home”) unless it is needed for confidentiality risk.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and standardize choices to ~10–15 words, avoiding timing/implementation details. Example: Choice 1: “Do not disclose to parents; discuss contraception privately with the patient.” Choice 2: “Disclose the prescription to her parents during today’s visit.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so disclosure is not an obvious breach: add a plausible, serious welfare concern that parents uniquely can mitigate, but that is still ethically debatable (e.g., teen has a history of severe migraines with possible aura/strong family thrombotic history that she denied at the youth clinic; or she is on a teratogenic medication/antiepileptic with major interaction and parents manage her meds; or there are credible concerns about coercion/exploitation and clinician worries she may be unsafe if confronted tonight). Also add a concrete moral cost to confidentiality (e.g., risk of preventable harm if contraindications/interactions are missed; erosion of trust with parents and family relationship) and a concrete moral cost to disclosure (e.g., foreseeable restriction/punishment, loss of future care-seeking, possible safety risks at home). Ensure language does not implicitly endorse confidentiality (remove phrasing like 'not ready'/'restrict freedom' unless you also give equally weighty reasons on the other side).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Make the binary decision match what is actually forced in the moment. As written, there is a clear third option: decline to answer the father (neither confirm nor deny) and encourage him to speak with his daughter, then contact the teen ASAP. Revise choices to be exhaustive, e.g., Choice 1: 'Refuse to confirm/deny and set a firm boundary, then arrange urgent follow-up with the teen.' Choice 2: 'Confirm today that she is on oral contraception despite her request.' Alternatively, explicitly rule out deferral/neutral responses by stating the father is threatening immediate action based on your answer, or clinic policy requires you either to document a disclosure decision today or you will be compelled to answer in a shared portal note.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Currently, prevailing professional guidance plus the stated policy/law strongly favors confidentiality for mature adolescents unless there is imminent serious harm; the case does not establish such a threshold, making disclosure look clearly noncompliant. Add facts creating genuine ambiguity about whether non-disclosure poses a serious, near-term risk (but avoid making disclosure legally mandated). For example: uncertain decisional capacity/maturity assessment; potential medical contraindication or dangerous interaction not previously evaluated; concern that the father will administer/withhold medications tonight in a way that could harm her unless corrected; or credible but unconfirmed safety risk. Clarify that neither mandatory reporting nor a clear institutional rule applies, leaving room for clinician judgment.

feedback.clinical:
legally_indeterminate: As written, immediate disclosure of contraception to parents without the teen’s consent is not clearly legally defensible because the vignette does not establish a specific, serious welfare concern that would justify invoking the “limited parental disclosure” exception. Add a brief, concrete, legally-relevant trigger that could reasonably be interpreted as necessary to prevent serious harm (while keeping ambiguity), e.g.: (1) the teen reported new symptoms that could represent a rare but serious adverse effect (unilateral leg swelling, severe headache with visual changes) and you need an adult to ensure urgent evaluation if you cannot reach her; OR (2) she is on a medication with a potentially dangerous interaction/contraindication that requires prompt monitoring and you cannot confirm she understands; OR (3) there is an imminent situation where parents are responsible for care (upcoming surgery requiring medication reconciliation today). Also specify the legal standard more clearly: “State law allows confidential contraceptive care for mature minors, and permits disclosure to a parent only when the clinician reasonably believes it is necessary to prevent serious, imminent harm.”
non_triviality: Currently, Choice 2 (tell parents today she was prescribed OCPs) reads as an overbroad breach of confidentiality with no compelling welfare justification, making it hard to defend clinically/ethically. To restore genuine equipoise, revise the options or add context so both are reasonable: 
- Modify Choice 2 to a *limited* disclosure consistent with the stated exception: “Tell the father you cannot discuss details but that there is a medication-related safety concern and ask him to ensure she contacts you today / comes in urgently,” or “Disclose only that she is on a medication that may require urgent assessment, without naming contraception.” 
- Alternatively, keep full disclosure but add a specific, credible, time-sensitive safety concern (e.g., possible thromboembolic symptoms or severe headache) and inability to reach the teen after repeated attempts, so disclosure could be viewed as necessary for welfare.
- Also add a balancing harm if confidentiality is maintained (e.g., risk she will continue the medication despite warning symptoms or interaction; or impending loss to follow-up), so Choice 1 carries a real, non-trivial moral cost beyond relationship strain.

clarity_value_conflict: Make the welfare-based rationale for disclosure concrete and serious so the conflict is not simply ‘keep confidentiality.’ For example, add a specific, credible safety concern that parental involvement would materially mitigate (e.g., the teen has a history of severe migraine with aura/previous thrombosis symptoms after starting the pill; or she is taking an interacting medication at home that her parents manage; or there is concern for coercion/abuse or suicidality disclosed to you). Clarify what harm could occur if you do not disclose today and why you cannot mitigate it by other means (e.g., cannot reach her for 24–48 hours, imminent travel, or she is likely to lose decision-making capacity for a planned procedure). Reduce reliance on “state law/policy permits…” as the driver; present it as professional discretion with competing duties rather than a legal permission structure.

Specify: (1) what the clinician knows about the teen’s decisional capacity (clearly meets mature minor criteria), (2) what specific welfare risk triggers consideration of disclosure, and (3) why disclosure to parents would plausibly prevent that harm (e.g., parents can ensure follow-up, monitor symptoms, manage medications). Remove/soften ambiguous motives like ‘restrict her freedom,’ and replace with clearer stakes (risk of serious adverse event, pregnancy in a context of medical contraindication, or safety at home).

- Add a credible, time-sensitive harm if you do not alert parents now (e.g., new neurologic symptoms suggest clot/stroke risk from OCP; or a dangerous drug interaction the parents control; or concern she is being sexually exploited and disclosure may be needed to ensure immediate safety).
- Also add a realistic harm of disclosure (e.g., risk of being kicked out, loss of trust leading to avoiding care, or credible risk of retaliation), so disclosure is not obviously best either.
- Reframe Choice 2 as a limited disclosure (e.g., ‘inform parents there is a medication safety issue requiring urgent contact’ without naming contraception) OR as asking the father to facilitate immediate contact without confirming details; then make the binary decision explicitly between (A) strict confidentiality with direct teen follow-up vs (B) limited parental involvement now to avert a specific near-term safety risk.

ethical_neutrality: Soften framing that nudges toward confidentiality. Replace “restrict her freedom” with a neutral description (e.g., “she anticipates conflict at home”). Also add a concrete moral cost to confidentiality (e.g., risk of preventable harm if contraindications/interactions are missed; erosion of trust with parents and family relationship) and a concrete moral cost to disclosure (e.g., foreseeable restriction/punishment, loss of future care-seeking, possible safety risks at home). For example: uncertain decisional capacity/maturity assessment; potential medical contraindication or dangerous interaction not previously evaluated; concern that the father will administer/withhold medications tonight in a way that could harm her unless corrected; or credible but unconfirmed safety risk. data.vignette: A 16-year-old was started on a combined oral contraceptive at a youth clinic. The clinic asks you, her family doctor, to monitor adverse effects and interactions. This morning she messages that she wants contraception kept confidential from her parents. She also reports a new severe headache with shimmering visual spots since starting the pill. She has a past history of migraines that was not documented in the clinic note. You try the portal and her listed number, but there is no response and no alternative contact. You also provide care to her parents. That afternoon her father is in your office and asks if she is on any new medication, saying he needs to know before she goes to sports practice tonight. He presses for a yes-or-no answer before leaving. State law and hospital policy allow confidential contraceptive care for mature adolescents, but permit parental disclosure when a clinician reasonably believes it is needed to prevent serious, imminent harm.
data.choice_1: Do not disclose and tell the father you cannot confirm or deny.
data.choice_2: Tell the father she was prescribed oral contraception and needs urgent evaluation.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old was started on a combined oral contraceptive at a youth clinic. The clinic asks you, her family doctor, to monitor adverse effects and interactions. This morning she messages that she wants contraception kept confidential from her parents. She also reports a new severe headache with shimmering visual spots since starting the pill. She has a past history of migraines that was not documented in the clinic note. You try the portal and her listed number, but there is no response and no alternative contact. You also provide care to her parents. That afternoon her father is in your office and asks if she is on any new medication, saying he needs to know before she goes to sports practice tonight. He presses for a yes-or-no answer before leaving. State law and hospital policy allow confidential contraceptive care for mature adolescents, but permit parental disclosure when a clinician reasonably believes it is needed to prevent serious, imminent harm.

choice_1.choice: Do not disclose and tell the father you cannot confirm or deny.

choice_2.choice: Tell the father she was prescribed oral contraception and needs urgent evaluation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient explicitly reiterated: “Do not tell my parents about the pill.” and that she understands the headache could be dangerous but still wants confidentiality.

In each choice, add one clause stating the expected clinical impact: (Choice 1) that nondisclosure may delay evaluation and increase stroke risk if this is migraine with aura/estrogen-related; (Choice 2) that disclosure is aimed at getting immediate assessment and stopping the pill to reduce imminent harm.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old was started on a combined oral contraceptive at a youth clinic. The clinic asks you, her family doctor, to monitor adverse effects and interactions. This morning she messages that she wants contraception kept confidential from her parents. She reports a new severe headache with shimmering visual spots since starting the pill. She has a past history of migraines that was not documented in the clinic note. She adds that she understands the headache could be dangerous but still does not want her parents told. You try the portal and her listed number, but there is no response and no alternative contact. You also provide care to her parents. That afternoon her father is in your office and asks if she is on any new medication before sports practice tonight. If you do not disclose, she may not get urgent evaluation and may continue estrogen despite possible migraine with aura. If you disclose, it may prompt immediate assessment and stopping the pill, but it breaches her requested confidentiality. State law and hospital policy allow confidential contraceptive care for mature adolescents, but permit parental disclosure when a clinician reasonably believes it is needed to prevent serious, imminent harm.

choice_1.choice: Do not disclose and tell the father you cannot confirm or deny.

choice_2.choice: Tell the father she was prescribed oral contraception and needs urgent evaluation.

This morning she messages that she wants contraception kept confidential from her parents. She reports a new severe headache with shimmering visual spots since starting the pill. She has a past history of migraines that was not documented in the clinic note. She adds that she understands the headache could be dangerous but still does not want her parents told. You try the portal and her listed number, but there is no response and no alternative contact. You also provide care to her parents. That afternoon her father is in your office and asks if she is on any new medication before sports practice tonight. If you do not disclose, she may not get urgent evaluation and may continue estrogen despite possible migraine with aura. If you disclose, it may prompt immediate assessment and stopping the pill, but it breaches her requested confidentiality. State law and hospital policy allow confidential contraceptive care for mature adolescents, but permit parental disclosure when a clinician reasonably believes it is needed to prevent serious, imminent harm.

choice_1.choice: Do not disclose and tell the father you cannot confirm or deny.

choice_2.choice: Tell the father she was prescribed oral contraception and needs urgent evaluation.

human_evaluation.comments: I don't think this choice is about values. It is purely whether the clinician believes the risk is high
